comments.commentBody:
1. NEWSWORTHY METS: Bill in Beijing is always perspicacious. He observed today: I do wish that the Times would publish a bit more about the Yankees, even though it's the off-season. I agree.

In fairness to The Times, it is reasonable to publish more on the Mets, because of their greater baseball needs and legal problems.

2. OKAJIMA WAS OK: As for Okajima, the post omitted his strong season in 2008 (2.61 ERA). Yes, 2010 and 2011 were bad. His ERA in 2010 was 97 and in 2011 was 103.

See http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/o/okajihi01.shtml

To paraphrase Henny Youngman, when asked about Okajima, I say compared to what. Four of the Yankee holdovers had ERA in 2011 of 77 (Hughes), 86 (Burnett), 99 (Noesi), and 108 (Soriano).

Let us give him a chance.

Okajima was bad for the Sox
Not called up when they were on the rocks
The Yanks need a lefty reliever
Who won’t be a deceiver
Let’s see if Hideki likes lox.
The best reason to support Paul that I can see is his willingness to draw down the military. But the idea that congress can keep a president from doing anything dangerous is laughable.

This article's main point sounds plausible, and I hope its author is right. A win in Iowa for Ron Paul would force the mainstream media to be less dismissive of what Paul represents.

Most voters only consider the candidates placed right in front of them by the mainstream corporate-owned media, even though those candidates made themselves visible by taking legal bribes (campaign contributions). And then they complain about how the politicians they elect answer to the people whose money made those candidates visible.

We don't have to wait for anyone to change the campaign finance system. We can simply refuse to vote for any candidate backed by big money. That denies power to the source of that money, bypassing the need for reform (and the lobbyists who would stop that reform because their jobs would be threatened).

Most voters would not vote for a candidate who had been convicted of bribery, no matter how "electable" he/she is or what his/her policy positions are. So why vote for any candidate who accepts legal bribes in the form of special interest money?

For the purpose of running for President, Ron Paul has exhibited lousy judgment by pandering to racists. This makes me wish we had a better candidate who doesn't take influence money. Until I see such a person, I'll continue to support Paul.

I don't worry about Ron Paul's weird ideas. Congress will limit Dr. Paul from doing anything dangerous as President. As President, he would not write laws; Congress does that.

I think you missed the point. The church isn’t being forced to close. They made a CHOICE to close because they disagree with a stipulation tied to Government money. There is a big difference in choosing to close and a violation of freedom of religion. Shame, shame on the church. They are punishing thousands of kids to make a political point.
No tax dollars for bigots.  Plain and simple.

Its alaso an attempt to keep their vile crimes out of the spotlight re the 24 hour news cycle.

Sorry church, but we will never forget what you have done to the GLBT community.

Including laying the foundation with the Blood libel and Deicide statements that over a millenia created the hatred that resulted in the holocaust of not only 6 million Jews and Germany's gays and many million others. By a man baptised catholic in 1888 in very catholic Austria.

What the Catholic Church seems to be missing is that we want freedom from their religion. They can do whatever they want in their organizations but many of us are persecuted by the Catholic Church and do not want our tax dollars funding their religion.

This coupled with the Chicago Cardinal conflating the lgbt community with the KKK puts me over the top.

Why would this institution try to set itself up to be a moral arbiter? Don't they have plenty to deal with regarding the sexual crimes that happened under their supervision? What part of child rape don't we understand?
The  Church has done good things. They've also done some evil as well, particularly in the cover-up of child sexual abuse and rape.

The Bishop of Rockville Centre was nicknamed Mansion Murphy by journalist Jimmy Breslin a few years ago. Murphy spent a fortune to renovate the Bishop's residence, including a luxury kitchen. Murphy displaced several nuns who had been living in the residence or nearby, and then fired several other nuns from their positions in local colleges. Bishops are free to use church funds as they see fit, but they also want the taxpayers to fund church charities. In this case, Murphy could have simply used the million(s) to save a Catholic school, or create an after-school program, but he didn't. What say you?

"That Rick Santorum home schools his kids,"

Really? That's the best you can come up with about why a candidate shouldn't be president?

What's so bad about home schooling your kids?

Why has the media seemingly decided that the rest of the country cares a fig about the outcome of the Iowa caucuses? I have a few Iowan friends, but, honestly, does this haven of evangelicals and libertarians really represent this country? I think not, and neither Iowa nor New Hampshire (first caucus and first primary) matter so much to the rest of American voters.

I wish the media would concentrate on the successes and failures of THIS Administration compared to others. That Rick Santorum home schools his kids, or that Newt Gingrich has had more wives than I have kids, and whose Contract With America was designed only for the rich, or that Rick Perry is double-dipping but can't remember what Departments he would cut, or that Ron Paul is both anti-gay and xenophobic, or that John Huntsman is smart but not smart enough to put together a campaign, or that Michelle Bachmann can't get some help from Sarah Palin or whomever, is interesting but irrelevant.

Most of us have never experienced a recession such as this, but I know one thing for sure. The Republican Party's mantra of NO is a major reason for the failure to work together to solve problems
we will apparently face for years.

They may want a one-term president, but I've yet to hear something from Republicans that will appeal to other than the rich. What I'd really like the media to cover is the Republican answer to our economic woes, other than a higher Defense Budget and a failed trickle-down economic plan.

Make no mistake.  President Obama will work with the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the U.N. if Iran tries to pull a naval blockade of the Strait of Hormuz.  With certain, actionable intelligence on the location of Iran's nuclear engineering sites, the oil will continue to flow and the construction of atomic weapons will be blown to kingdom come.  No insane, illegitimate dictator of Iran will have his way with the United States of America with this or any other president in office.  Those detractors of the president and his foreign policy are loathe to accept the strength of his patriotism or his steadfast determination to protect American interests here or abroad.  Ask Gaddafi, bin Laden, and John McCain how it feels to go up against President Obama.  He loves our country and will defend it.  Failure is not an option.

"We must not let our rulers load us with perpetual debt. We must make our selection between economy and liberty or profusion and servitude. If we run into such debts as that we must be taxed in our meat in our drink, in our necessities and comforts, in our labors and in our amusements, for our callings and our creeds...our people.. must come to labor sixteen hours in the twenty-four, give earnings of fifteen of these to the government for their debts and daily expenses; and the sixteenth being insufficient to afford us bread, we must live.. We have not time to think, no means of calling the mis-managers to account, but be glad to obtain subsistence by hiring ourselves to rivet their chains on the necks of our fellow suffers. Our landholders, too...retaining indeed the title and stewardship of estates called theirs, but held really in trust for the treasury, must...be contented with penury, obscurity and exile.. private fortunes are destroyed by public as well as by private extravagance.

This is the tendency of all human governments. A departure from principle becomes a precedent for a second; that second for a third; and so on, till the bulk of society is reduced to mere automatons of misery, to have no sensibilities left but for sinning and suffering... And the fore horse of this frightful team is public debt. Taxation follows that, and in its train wretchedness and oppression." Thomas Jefferson

To Emmanuel and Chess GM -

Iran is threatening to obstruct shipping if stronger sanctions are put into place to block its pursuit of nuclear weapons. Iran's Vice-President Mohammad Reza Rahimi warned that his nation would block the vital Strait of Hormuz if proposed sanctions on Iranian crude oil exports are imposed. Approximately 33-1/3% of the world’s shipped crude oil passes through this strategic shipping channel and any shutdown could have devastating repercussions for the global economy.

Iran is the only UN member that has committed to destroying another UN member - Iranian leaders have called for Israel to be “wiped off the map.” Despite years of claiming its nuclear program was peaceful, the International Atomic Energy Agency concluded in a damning report in November that Iran was likely developing nuclear weapons.

“An Iran with nuclear weapons would confront the world with many dangers, including the very real danger that it will trigger a nuclear war in the Middle East,” said Dennis Ross, the former Middle East peace negotiator and advisor to President Obama.
All basic truth NYT couldve easilly found if they had made any serious objective resaerch.

Yes, indeed: ' It's LAUGHABLE to have judges and attorneys "judging" the "validity" or "quality" of artworks, about which they have no knowledge or experience; this proves exactly what's wrong with the entire present system.
In our world overrun by attorneys and bean-counters Duchamp and Warhol would have been imprisoned.' Agree.!

From the article regarding Prince's work: "$2.5 million for one of the works. (“Wow — yeah,” Mr. Prince said when a lawyer asked him under oath in the district court case if that figure was correct.) "

The creative talent here is that much Mr. Prince, whose work has gone into the toilet in the last few years (some would say, since leaving Barbara Gladstone), but his mega-powerful dealer, Larry Gagosian, who is a greater taste-maker and marketer than many of his artists are as artists.

I wonder if Mr. Gagosian were to quit the scene what would happen to prices of his stable of artists and to the art market in general.
Inter-textuality, indeed!

"Virginia Rutledge, an art lawyer and former general counsel for Creative Commons, a nonprofit group that advocates for more open copyright standards, said she believed that the problem facing the art world was as much a “cultural attribution crisis” as a legal crisis and that the problem could be at least partly addressed by cultivating a stronger climate of simple acknowledgement and credit. "
I can't *believe* she rated 4th place in today's obits. Good grief.
Clearly we need tort reform to prevent those suffering from collecting with jack pot justice cases, and McDonalds hot coffeee...and blah blah blah...
This is why we need Dr. Don Berwick.
Heart is one of the best bands ever.

To suggest that Massachusetts voters are less inclined to ever vote for a woman than voters in other states (including Texas and South Carolina, where women were elected to state-wide office) is ridiculous.  Remote viewing is a poor way to predict political contests in areas one is not familiar with.

Like you, (I assume) I have not spent much time at occupy Oakland, but I also don't presume to know that the participants are a bunch of lazy dimwits. In fact the one day I did go just to see what is was all about,(on 12/12, the day of the port shut down) I ran into a family friend who I was surprised to learn, is  intimately involved with the Occupy movement. She also happens to be an intelligent woman who is a full time paramedic and a single mom. Evidence that you don't what the hell you're talking about.

I disagree with you, my new york city cat was killed by either a snake or a car once we moved to the suburbs. he survived a lot in the city, various apartments, rennovations, was a great cat. but didn't survive the suburbs.

This is a remarkably fair article in an almost miraculous day for the electronic edition of the Times. There are two columns discussing Republicans containing ZERO cheap shots. Oh, well, I am sure th usual Leftist dogma returns forthwith.

Reassuringly, the commenters still Blame Bush. Every one of their ocean of liberals will guarantee Mr. Obama the 15% of the electorate they represent.

The social conservatives' message is very realistic, although they don't talk much about import quotes or teriffs, which will probably be needed to really get manufacturing going here. I am always disappointed with what politicos of either party actually say about manufacturing when discussing employment. We have got to get making things a front-and-center issue in this county once again.

Then some serious tort reform and a war on over-regulation will finish off the actual 11.6% unemployment rate.

Perhaps the reason why they are removed from the photo stems from the fact three of the people and the camera are turned away from the procession of kim jong il. Perhaps in a society which reveres and respects both kim jong il and kim il sung as practically (if not) gods this would be a sign of disrespect especially since its just as the procession reaches them.
